questions.text: Certain inositol-containing phospholipids are cleaved resulting in the formation of diacyglycerol and which other second messenger?
questions.solution:
• Inositol-containing phospholipids form minor components of cell membranes. They are also called phosphoinositides.
  • Examples of these phosphoinositides include phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) and phosphatidylinositol 3,4,5-trisphosphate (PIP3).
  • Most phosphoinositides undergo dephosphorylation by various families of phosphatases.
  • PIP2 is the only phophoinositide that undergoes cleavage by the action of the phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C (PLC) isozymes.
  • This cleavage results in the formation of two second messengers called diacylglycerol (DAG) and inositol trisphophaste (IP3).
    This can be remembered as PIP2 + PLC à DAG + IP3.
  • DAG has a role in the activation of protein kinase C, after it is released into the plane of the plasma membrane.
  • IP3 enters the cytosol and it instigates the release of intracellular Ca2+ from the endoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causing central nervous infections is matched correctly with its epidemiology?

choices.text: Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus – Wild rodent exposure
Baylisascaris procyonis -  Warm fresh water swimming

questions.solution:
• Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) is transmitted to humans by wild rodents or common house mouse/rats by aerosols of excreta or secreta. LCMV causes lymphocytic choriomeningitis or meningoencephalitis.
  • Primary amebic meningoencephalitis can be caused by Naeglaria fowleri which is usually acquired by humans after an episode of warm, fresh water swimming.
  • Bartonella henselae is the causative organism of cat-scratch disease (CSD) which is transmitted to humans by exposure to cats. CSD can progress to severe neurological complications like cerebellitis and encephalopathy.
  • Baylisascaris procyonis is a nematode which can cause eosinophilic meningoencephalitis after the ingestion of its eggs. This occurs when there is exposure to raccoon excreta.

questions.text: A 62 year old man has a history of diabetes, hypertension and hyperlipidemia and now presents with left hemiparesis with no speech problems. His symptoms resolve while he is being evaluated. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: The patient can be discharged with follow up in 3 months and treatment change is not necessary
Observation before thrombolysis is indicated prior to symptom resolution, to evaluate if the patient has a transient ischemic attack rather than a stroke
MRI is not necessary since the symptoms have resolved
The risk of stroke is highest in the period immediately following and soon after a transient ischemic attack

questions.solution:
• In the above case, the patient has a transient ischemic attack (TIA).
  • TIA is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke like symptoms) owing to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea; that lasts for less than 24 hours.
  • Most TIAs usually last for less than one hour to a few minutes.
  • It is a prognostic indicator for stroke with approximately 10-15% risk of developing stroke in the following 3 months after a TIA. Stroke can occur as soon as 2 days after a TIA.
  • Thus, a TIA should be evaluated urgently to assess the risk of stroke, usually with an MRI.
  • There is no room for observation in the management of patient with TIA but the improvement characteristic of TIA contraindicates thrombolysis.
  • Risk stratification of stroke in patients with TIA can be done using the ABCD2 score which is as in the table below.
Age 60 or older 1 point
Blood pressure ≥140/90 1 point

Clinical:

Unilateral weakness

Speech impairment

2 points

1 point

Duration:

60 minutes or more

<60 minutes

2 points

1 point
Diabetes mellitus 1 point

questions.text: Among the following, which is the earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy?
questions.solution:
The earliest sensation to be lost in leprosy is hot temperature.

The sensations are lost in the following order:

  • Temperature (inability to distinguish hot and cold)
  • Light touch
  • Pain
  • Deep touch

Leprosy (Hansen disease) is a chronic infective granulomatous disease caused by the bacillus Mycobacterium leprae.

Leprosy is clinically characterized by one or more of the following features :

  • Numbness
  • Hypopigmented patches
  • Erythematous macules over cheeks, upper arms, thighs, and buttocks may be present.
  • Partial or total loss of cutaneous sensation in the affected areas 
  • Presence of thickened nerves
  • Presence of acid-fast bacilli in the skin or nasal smears.

Classification systems of leprosy:

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
  • Madrid classification:
    • Lepromatous (LL)
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline/dimorphous
    • Indeterminate (early unstable type)
  • Indian classification - includes categories under Madrid classification + pure neuritic type

    The spectrum of leprosy in India in decreasing order of prevalence: 

    1. Borderline tuberculoid 
    2. Borderline lepromatous
    3. Lepromatous leprosy
    4. Pure neuritic type
    5. Borderline-borderline
    6. Indeterminate type
    7. Histoid type 
  • WHO classification:
 

Paucibacillary Leprosy

As per the NLEP guidelines, a patient with paucibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin and dapsone for 6 months. The dose of rifampicin is 600 mg, and it is given monthly under supervision. The dose of dapsone is 100 mg and has to be taken by the patient every day.

A patient with multibacillary leprosy is treated with rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone for 12 months. Rifampicin 600 mg and clofazimine 300 mg are given every month under supervision. Dapsone 100 mg and clofazimine 50 mg should be taken by the patient every day.

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with a port-wine nevus on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. On radiological examination, the given appearance of the skull is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image of the skull showing tram track sign (gyriform calcification in a curvilinear pattern), along with the history of port-wine nevus and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas point to a diagnosis of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome is characterized by a port-wine nevus (along the course of the trigeminal nerve) on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas. It is a congenital syndrome.

There is an increased risk of seizures and intracranial calcifications in the child before 2 years of age. There may be associated hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay. The ocular findings commonly associated are choroidal hemangioma, iris heterochromia, visual field defects, and ipsilateral glaucoma.

Images show port-wine stain associated with Sturge–Weber syndrome.


Features of MRI brain include

  • Pial angioma is seen as a diffuse pial enhancement of variable thickness.
  • Enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilatation of transparenchymal veins that communicate between the superficial and deep cerebral venous systems 

MRI and CT show intracranial calcification respectively. The tram-track sign in the brain refers to the parallel calcification of the cerebral cortex.


Other options:

Option A: Moya-moya disease is characterized by dilatation of collateral vessels resulting from stenosis of the internal carotid artery appearing as puff of smoke pattern on angiography.

Option C: Von Hippel Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant multiorgan disorder characterized by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas and pheochromocytomas with an increased risk of developing renal cell carcinomas.

Option D: Tuberous sclerosis is a multi-system neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomyolipomas, cysts in kidneys, multiple hamartomas, giant cell astrocytomas, and cortical tubers.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Witzelsucht refers to:

choices.text: Involuntary repetition of another person’s actions

questions.solution:
• Witzelsucht is a term used for inappropriate humor where lewd jokes and socially unacceptable puns are used in inappropriate places.
  • This is also called as an inappropriate jocular affect.
  • This can be seen in patients with the emotional disorder called pathological laughing and crying (PLAC).
  • The extreme of these emotions can be elicited in some patients by something as small as a wave of the hand by the examiner.
  • Witzelsucht can be localized to the right-hemispheric lesions, especially when involving the frontal lobe.
  • Involuntary repetition or imitation of another’s action is called echopraxia which can be seen in Tourette’s syndrome.
  • Social disinhibition is a blanket term that refers to a lack of restraint and disregard for social conventions, boundaries and etiquette. It also involves poor risk assessment.
  • Akinetic mutism is the absence of voluntary motor movement and speech in an otherwise alert patient. It is seen in psychotic depression and catatonic states.

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly paired to show the relationship between a brain area and a type of memory?

choices.text: Medial temporal lobe and declarative memory

questions.solution:
Declarative memory involves the hippocampus and the medial temporal lobe for retention.

Priming - neocortex.

Procedural memory - striatum.

Associative learning-  amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses.

Nonassociative learning -  various reflex pathways.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of cerebral edema?
questions.solution:
Hypernatermia does not cause cerebral edema but hyponatremia causes it.

Acute cerebral edema is generally seen in hyponatremia due to the following mechanism:

Acute hyponatremia->Increased interstitial pressure -> Shunting of extracellular fluid (ECF) and solutes from interstitial space to CSF and then systemic circulation-> Efflux of Na+, K+, and Cl- from brain cells -> Rapid decrease in tonicity overwhelms regulatory mechanisms -> Acute hyponatremic encephalopathy -> Acute cerebral edema.

  • Lead and Cerebral Edema: Toxic effects of systemic lead exposure manifest in the CNS generally as acute encephalopathy in children and polyneuropathy in adults. Cerebral edema, especially of the white matter is most commonly seen in children with lead intoxication.
  • Liver Failure and Cerebral Edema: Acute liver failure commonly causes brain edema, seizures, and agitation. Brain edema has been linked to persistent hyperammonemia in acute liver failure. Brain edema is one of the leading causes of mortality in acute liver failure.
  • High-Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE): HACE is a condition in the spectrum of altitude-related neurologic disorders that occurs in rapid ascent. It is an encephalopathy that rapidly causes ataxia and altered consciousness with diffuse cerebral involvement but without focal neurological deficits.

questions.text: Seizures occur characteristically in which stage of SSPE
questions.solution:
Massive myoclonus and seizures are characteristic of Stage II of Subacute Sclerosing Pan Encephalitis

Clinical stages of subacute sclerosis panencephalitis:

 

Stage  Clinical manifestations 
Stage I  Personality changes, failure in school, strange behaviour  
Stage II  Massive, repetitive, and frequent myoclonic jerks, seizures and dementia  
Stage III  Rigidity, extrapyramidal symptoms, and progressive unresponsiveness  
Stage IV  Coma, vegetative state, autonomic failure, and akinetic mutism

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in which of the following ovarian tumors:
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies is a histopathological finding of serous cyst adenoma of ovary.

  • They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration.
  • Its presence per se does not denote malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following drug that is used for Parkinson disease acts on Adenosine A2a Receptor?
questions.solution:
Istradefylline is a selective antagonist of Adenosine A2a receptor that is used in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease.

Drugs used in treatment of Parkinson’s disease:

  • Levodopa, Carbidopa, Benserazide – On Dopa decarboxylase (DDC)
  • Entacapone, Tolcapone - catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT)
  • Selegiline, Rasagiline – MAO-B inhibitors
  • Pramipexole, Ropinirole, Rotigotine, Bromocriptine, Apomorphine – Dopamine receptors
  • Orphenadrine, procyclidine, trihexyphenidyl, Benztropine, Biperiden – Central anticholinergic
  • Amantadine – NMDA blocking agent
  • Istradefylline, preladenant -  Adenosine A2A receptor antagonists
  • Sarizotan - 5-HT1A antagonists

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Toxoplasma gondii?

choices.text: Tachyzoites replicate in all mammalian cells excluding red blood cells
Definitive hosts include humans and sheep
There is greater risk if the time between infection of mother and conception is >6months due to reactivation of T. gondii
Transmission occurs only through oral and trans-placental routes

questions.solution:
• Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis.
  • Life cycle of T. gondii
    • Asexual stage: Oocysts containing sporozoites or tissue cysts containing bradyzoites are ingested by intermediate hosts like humans, sheep, etc. Bradyzoites and sporozoites are released in the intestinal epithelium and form tachyzoites, which divide rapidly and replicates in all mammalian cells except for red blood cells. Tissue cysts are then formed which can occur in various organs but principally persist in the central nervous system. This chronic stage completes the asexual cycle and thus the parasite completes its life cycle in the intermediate host.
    • The definitive host is the cat in which the sexual stage takes place. In this stage, the oocysts are formed, which after sporulation are excreted and if ingested by an intermediate host, causes pathological changes.
  • Transmission of human Toxoplasma infection
    • This can be through oral routes from contaminated water or food, etc; it can be transmitted through blood or organs (transfusion or transplantation) and it can be transmitted through the trans-placental route.
    • There is essentially no risk of trans-placental transmission if the mother is infected 6 months or more before conception.
    • If the time between infection and conception is <6 months, then the risk of transplacental transmission is high.
    • If the mother becomes infected during the 1st trimester, the incidence of transplacental transmission is low but the disease in the neonate would be more severe.
    • If infection occurs during the 3rd trimester, the incidence of transmission is the highest but the neonate is usually asymptomatic.

questions.text: Pheochromocytomas are associated with the following syndromes except?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN-2, Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and Neurofibromatosis type 1. Cowden syndrome is caused by PTEN mutations and can be associated with multiple hamartomas of skin, breast, and mucous membranes, breast cancer, and neuroendocrine tumors.

Pheochromocytomas may occur in isolation or be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes. The latter include the following tumor syndromes which are characterized by unique germline mutations of genes. 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by NF1 germline mutations.
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome - Germline mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes.
  • MEN2 - Activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - Germline mutations in VHL gene.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Measurement of the plasma metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid a hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Axonotmesis is defined as:

choices.text: The disruption of axons and myelin
The disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes
The temporary failure of nerve function without physical axon disruption
The temporary failure of nerve function with physical axon disruption

questions.solution:
Axonotmesis  is the disruption of axons and myelin

Seddon classification of peripheral nerve injury:

  • Neurapraxia - Axon degeneration does not occur and there is return of normal axonal function occurs over hours to months, often in the 2-4 week range.
  • Axonotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and myelin with intact surrounding connective tissue. Axons degenerate proximally and distally from the area of injury. Distal degeneration is called Wallerian degeneration. Recovery may occur after 18 months.
  • Neurotmesis: It is the disruption of axons and endoneurial tubes and degeneration of proximal and distal axons occurs.

Retinoblastoma is most common intra-ocular malignancy of children
Sebaceous cell carcinoma is more common  in upper eyelid
Most common primary intra-ocular malignancy of Adults -Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: Pupils in stage 2 of hypoxic ischaemic encephalopathy show
questions.solution:
Pupils at different stages of Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy

  • Stage 1 - Mydriasis
  • Stage 2 - Miosis
  • Stage 3 - Unequal, poor light reflex

Stages of HIE :

  • Hyperactive tendon reflexes may be seen in stage 1 and 2, however the infant is hyper alert with mydriasis and normal EEG findings in stage 1. Muscle tone and posture are normal and prognosis is good.
  • In stage 2, the infant is lethargic and hypotonic, with miosis and EEG showing low voltage which changes to seizure activity. Seizures are common in this stage. The infant has a flexed posture. Hyperactive tendon reflexes and myoclonus are present. Prognosis is variable.
  • In stage 3, the infant is stuporous or comatose with decerebrate posture and absent tendon reflexes. Pupils are unequal and show poor light reflex. EEG is abnormal and prognosis is poor, resulting in death or severe deficits.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had undergone modified radical mastectomy followed by chemotherapy with trastuzumab. She now presents with liver metastases. Which of the following drugs could be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario depicts a case of trastuzumab-refractory breast cancer and lapatinib is used in this condition.

Drug Use
Lapatinib Refractory and metastatic breast carcinoma
Panitumumab Colorectal carcinoma
Erlotinib
  • Non small cell lung carcinoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
Imatinib
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumour

In 2018, Dacomitinib has been approved by FDA for the treatment of metastatic non-small-cell lung cancer. It is a selective and irreversible inhibitor of EGFR.

questions.text: In the following graph A, B , C correctly denotes

choices.text: A = N2O , B = Isoflurane , C = Halothane
A = Halothane , B = Isoflurane , C = N2O
A = Isoflurane , B = N2O , C = Halothane
A = N2O , B = Halothane , C = Isoflurane

questions.solution:
The given graph shows FA/Fi of various inhalational anaesthetics.

FA – Alveolar concentration of Gas

Fi  - Inspired gas concentration

Solubility of gas in a blood is one of the factors on which alveolar concentration of gas depends.

Nitrous oxide is a relatively insoluble agent and hence there is a higher concentration of FA. Hence it is the topmost curve.

Halothane is relatively soluble and hence is the bottom most curve.

Solubility of isoflurane lies between the two and hence is the middle curve.

questions.text: Which of the following typical antipsychotic has the least extrapyramidal effect?
questions.solution:
Thioridazone has the least extrapyramidal effect.

Extrapyramidal effect are more 

  • prominent with high potency drugs like fluphenazine, haloperidol, pimozide
  • least with thioridazine, clozapine, and all other atypical antipsychotics, except higher dose of risperidone.

questions.text: Freiberg infarction predominantly affects the _________ bones.
questions.solution:
• Freiberg infarction (also known as Freiberg disease) involves the metatarsal bones, although it is the 2nd metatarsal that is most commonly involved.
  • It is a type of osteonecrosis of subchondral cancellous bone which is followed by a reparative process.
  • This condition is considered to follow a traumatic event and most commonly presents in the 2nd decade of life.
  • Features:
    • Repetitive microfractures, loss of bloody supply to subchondral bone and collapse of cancellous bone à cartilage deformation.
    • Synovitis may be prolonged and severe leading to limitation of motion.
    • Bicortical thickening of metatarsal shaft.
    • Osteochondral fragmentation occurs around the metatarsal head.
  • Conservative management: Modification of activities, semirigid orthoses, metatarsal bars and short leg walking cast with a toe extension (if all else fails).
  • Surgical treatment options include:
  • Resection of metatarsal head.
  • Elevation of depressed fragment of the metatarsal head and bone grafting of the defect.
  • Resection of the base of the proximal phalanx with syndactylization of 2nd and 3rd toes.
  • Dorsal wedge closing osteotomy of the metatarsal head.
  • Joint debridement and metatarsal head remodeling.
  • The following image shows a case of Freiberg disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Aicardi syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Aicardi syndrome is a rare X-linked dominant disorder which is almost exclusively seen in girls.
  • This disorder is lethal in the male fetus.
  • Aicardi syndrome consists of agenesis of corpus callosum, chorioretinal lacunae, vertebral anomalies, intellectual disability and myoclonic epilepsy.
  • Neuropathology in Aicardi syndrome – various minor dysplasias, agenesis of corpus callosum and anterior commissure; non-laminated polymicrogyric cortex with abnormally oriented neurons.
  • Chorioretinal lacunae (as shown below) are pathognomonic of Aicardi syndrome.
  • EEG in Aicardi syndrome (as shown below) typically shows asymmetry between the two hemispheres and an asynchronous burst suppression pattern.

questions.text: A child presents with neonatal hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements, and mental retardation. On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a ‘batwing appearance’ as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the Molar tooth sign suggest the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The image shows an axial T2 weighted image at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles demonstrating the molar tooth sign.

Joubert syndrome:

These are a group of recessive congenital ataxia disorders in which typically there is

  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Tachypnoea
  • Abnormal eye movements
  • Mental retardation associated with a particular pattern of cerebellar dysgenesis with a molar tooth-type malformation and vermis hypoplasia

MRI features :

  • The cardinal feature is the presence of a molar tooth sign which is created by a combination of
    • Midbrain hypoplasia with an
    • Abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and
    • A failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.
  • On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a batwing appearance
  • Cerebellar hypoplasia
  • Midline vermian cleft
  • Dysplastic small vermis
  • The midbrain is small

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Pilocytic astrocytoma?

choices.text: Gene mutation involving Serine threonine kinase BRAF
Has GFAP positive hair like projections

questions.solution:
Pilocytic astrocytoma are relatively benign tumours.

Pilocytic tumours:

  • Pilocytic astrocytomas are relatively benign tumors that typically affect children and young adults.
  • Most commonly located in the cerebellum, they also may involve the third ventricle, the optic pathways, the spinal cord, and occasionally the cerebral hemispheres.
  • There is often a cyst associated with the tumor
  • Tumors that involve the hypothalamus are especially problematic because they cannot be resected completely.
  • A high proportion of pilocytic astrocytomas have activating mutations or translocations involving the gene encoding the serine-threonine kinase BRAF, which result in activation of the MAPK signaling pathway.
  • Pilocytic astrocytomas do not have mutations in IDH1 and IDH2, supporting their distinction from the low-grade diffuse gliomas.
  • A pilocytic astrocytoma often is cystic, with a mural nodule in the wall of the cyst; if solid, it is usually well circumscribed.
  • The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive.
  • Rosenthal fibers, eosinophilic granular bodies, and microcysts are often present, while necrosis and mitoses are rare.

questions.text: Pottasium sparing diuretics are all except?
questions.solution:
Metolazone is a Thiazide like medium efficacy diuretic,that leads to electrolyte disturbances,  not potassium sparing diuretic.

Potassium sparing diuretics

  • Aldosterone antagonist: Spironolactone, Eplerenone
  • Inhibitors of renal epithelial Na+ channel: Triamterene, Amiloride.

questions.text: Which of the following mimics lead poisoning?
questions.solution:
• δ-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is similar to lead poisoning.
  • It is also called Plumboporphyria/Doss porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, though not related to lead exposure.
  • ALAD catalyses the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole PBG.
  • The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it.
  • Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and symptoms.
  • Symptoms resemble other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of abdominal pain and neuropathy.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria

Related Pearl: Presentation of Plumbism/Saturnism/Chronic Lead Poisoning

Mnemonic-ABCDEF

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

questions.text: A 57-year-old professor at a medical school experienced numerous episodes of a sudden loss of muscle tone and an irresistible urge to sleep in the middle of the afternoon. The diagnosis was narcolepsy. True about it is:

choices.text: Characterized by a sudden onset of NREM sleep
Has a familial incidence associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex
Due to the presence of an excessive number of orexin-producing neurons in the hypothalamus
Is the most common cause of daytime sleepiness

questions.solution:
Narcolepsy has a familial incidence strongly associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex on chromosome 6 at the HLA-DR2 or HLA-DQW1 locus, implying a genetic susceptibility.

  • Narcolepsy is a chronic neurologic disorder caused by the brain’s inability to regulate sleep–wake cycles normally.
  • The affected individual experiences a sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy), an eventual irresistible urge to sleep during daytime, and possibly brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep.
  • Narcolepsy is also characterized by a sudden onset of REM sleep, unlike normal sleep that begins with NREM, slow-wave sleep.
  • Compared to brains from healthy persons, the brains of persons with narcolepsy often contain fewer hypocretin (orexin)-producing neurons in the hypothalamus.
  • The most common cause of daytime sleepiness is Obstructive Sleep Apnoea.

questions.text: Absolute contraindications to neuraxial blockade include all except

choices.text: Infection at the site of injection

questions.solution:
Sepsis is a relative contraindication to neuraxial blockade.

Absolute contraindication :

  • Infection at the site of injection
  • Patient refusal
  • Coagulopathy or other bleeding diathesis
  • Severe hypovolemia
  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Severe aortic stenosis
  • Severe mitral stenosis

Relative contraindication :

  • Sepsis
  • Uncooperative patient
  • Pre-existing neurological deficits
  • Demyelinating lesions
  • Stenotic valvular heart lesions
  • Left ventricular outflow obstruction (hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy)
  • Severe spinal deformity

questions.text: All are features of neuroleptic malignant syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome is associated with Unstable BP

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)  :

  • It is associated with typical antipsychotics like phenothiazines.
  • Clinical features: Extreme muscle rigidity, fever, unstable BP, myoglobinemia and can be fatal.
  • Time of onset: weeks to months after initiation of antipsychotic therapy. Can persist for up to a week after discontinuation of the drug.
  • Probable mechanism: Dopamine antagonism.
  • Treatment: Stopping offending antipsychotic immediately, supportive care, dantrolene, and bromocriptine.

questions.text: What is the histological appearance of brain in Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease?
questions.solution:
Histological appearance of brain in Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease is spongiform change in brain.

Appearance of Creutzfeldt- Jacob disease:

  • The progression to death in CJD usually is so rapid that there is little macroscopic evidence of brain atrophy.
  • On microscopic examination, the pathognomonic finding is a spongiform     transformation of the cerebral cortex and deep gray matter structures (caudate, putamen)
  • This multifocal process results in the uneven formation of small, apparently empty, microscopic vacuoles of varying sizes within the neuropil (the eosinophilic regions in grey matter that contain dendrites, axons, and synapses) and sometimes in the perikaryon of neurons
  • In advanced cases, there is severe neuronal loss, reactive gliosis, and sometimes expansion of the vacuolated areas into cystlike spaces (“status spongiosus”)
  • No inflammatory infiltrate is present
  • Immunohistochemical staining demonstrates the presence of proteinase K–resistant PrPsc in tissue, while western blotting of tissue extracts after partial protease digestion allows detection of diagnostic PrPsc.

questions.text: The imaging modality that employs Blood Oxygen Level Dependent signal changes is :
questions.solution:
Blood Oxygen Level Dependent signal changes (BOLD) is the principle used in the fMRI(functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging)

Functional MRI (fMRI)

  • It is used to study cortical activation.
  • During cortical activation, there is an increase in relative cerebral blood flow (rCBF) and thus an increase in oxygen delivery to the activated brain, which exceeds the local oxygen metabolic requirement.
  • There is a net increase in oxyhemoglobin concentration in the venules and veins in the vicinity of the activated brain, which results in a tiny increase in MR signal, the so-called blood oxygenation level-dependent or, BOLD effect.
  • fMRI is mainly used for brain mapping.

 When neurons are activated the increased oxygen demand is met by increasing perfusion. This further rises venous oxyhemoglobin and reduces deoxyhemoglobin concentration. As deoxyhemoglobin is paramagnetic, the intensity of fMRI images increases in the activated areas. By performing different activities that activate different areas, a mapping can be done in fMRI.

Optical Coherence Tomography uses coherent light to obtain images of tissue in 2D or 3D up to micrometer resolutions. Currently, it is primarily employed in ophthalmology and interventional cardiology. The image in question shows a optical coherence tomography image of fluid accumulation in subretinal space with shallow retinal detachment.The following image shows OCT of a retina.


The following image shows an Intracoronary OCT image. The image shows a intracoronary plaque from 6 o'clock to 8 o’clock

Perfusion MRI is used to do assessment of tissue perfusion using a gadolinium contrast

SPECT is Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography that uses gamma rays to perform nuclear imaging that can provide 3D images also.

questions.text: Regarding endotracheal intubation in infants, which is true:

choices.text: Miller blade is used since it is straight
Macintosh blade is used since it provides greater room for passage
Miller blade is advantageous since it causes less damage to teeth
The size of the intubation tube used is 4.5 for full term infants

questions.solution:
• There are two types of laryngoscopic blades available for intubation:
    • Curved blade
    • Straight blade
  • Miller is the most commonly used straight blade and is used neonates, infants and young children, patients with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.
  • Macintosh is the most commonly used curved blade and is preferred for adults.
  • Advantage of curved blade:
  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth
  • Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm. In infants, it is 3.5 mm
Age Endoscopic - Internal diameter (mm) Length (cm)
Full-term infant 3.5         12
Child 4  + Age/4     12 + Age/2
Adult male 7.5 - 9.0          24
Adult female 7.0–7.5          24

questions.text: The bodies shown in the below image are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Lewy body. Lewy bodies may be found in the remaining neurons present in the substantia nigra in cases of Parkinson’s disease.

These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions. They have a dense core, surrounded by a pale halo. On ultrastructural examination, Lewy bodies consist of fine filaments, composed of α-synuclein and other proteins, including neurofilaments and ubiquitin. The other major histologic finding is the presence of Lewy neurites that also contain aggregated α-synuclein.

The microscopic feature of Parkinson's disease is pallor of the substantia nigra and locus ceruleus. This occurs due to the loss of pigmented, catecholaminergic neurons in these regions associated with gliosis.

Other options

Option A- Pick's disease is a type of front temporal lobar degeneration. The surviving neurons show a characteristic swelling (Pick cells), and others contain Pick bodies, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. 

The below image shows Pick bodies (marked with asterisks).

Option C- Microscopy of Huntington's disease shows loss of striatal neurons in the caudate nucleus, especially in the tail and in portions nearer the ventricle.

Option D- Important microscopic features of Alzheimer's disease are neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are focal collections of dilated, tortuous axons and dendritic processes. They are present around an amyloid core. Neurofibrillary tangles are tau-containing bundles of filaments in the cytoplasm of the neurons. They can be elongated, flame-shaped, or may be rounded. (globose tangles)

The below image on the right top shows neuritic plaques and on the left bottom shows the presence of neurofibrillary tangles.

questions.text: Which of the following belongs to the Bunyavirales order of viruses that cause encephalitis?
questions.solution:
• La Crosse virus belongs to the Bunyavirales order of viruses and it is a major cause of encephalitis and aseptic meningitis in countries like the US.
  • It is transmitted by mosquitoes, specifically the Ochlerotatus triseriatus (also called Aedes triseriatus).
  • Other encephalitis-causing members of the Bunyavirales order of viruses are California encephalitis virus, Lumbo virus and Inkoo virus.
  • West Nile virus belongs to the genus Flavivirus.

        Eastern equine encephalitis virus is a togavirus belonging to the genus Alphavirus.

       Colorado tick fever virus belongs to the genus Coltivirus under the family of viruses called Reoviridae.

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards left indicates
questions.solution:
It is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness.

Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man loses his right hand in a farm accident. Four years later, he has episodes of severe pain in the missing hand. A detailed PET scan study of his cerebral cortex might be expected to show:

choices.text: Expansion of the right hand area in his left primary somatosensory cortex
A metabolically inactive spot where his hand area in his left primary somatosensory cortex would normally be
Projection of fibres from neighbouring sensory areas into the right hand area of his right primary somatosensory cortex
Projection of fibres from neighbouring sensory areas into the right hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex

questions.solution:
A PET scan would show a projection of fibres from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

  • The above clinical scenario describes a phantom limb pain.
  • In a phantom limb, cortical plasticity occurs.
  • This means that there is a projection of fibres from neighbouring areas into the cortical area previously occupied by the phantom limb.
  • The sensory cortical area occupied by the Right hand is Left somatosensory cortex.

Cortical plasticity / Phantom limb

Features :

  • A phantom limb is the sensation that an amputated or missing limb is still attached.
  • Plasticity is the ability of the brain to adapt to such a condition by reorganization of thalamic and cortical structures.
  • If a digit is amputated in a monkey, the cortical representation of the neighbouring digits spreads into the cortical area that was previously occupied by the representation of the amputated digit.
  • The converse also holds true - If the cortical area representing a digit is removed, the somatosensory map of the digit moves to the surrounding cortex.

Diagnosis and Management :

  • PET scan is used to document these plastic changes in cortex.
  • Use of epidural analgesia during amputation surgery decreases incidence of phantom pain.
  • Spinal cord stimulation also helps in reducing phantom pain. (interferes with ascending impulses to brain)

questions.text: All of the following are known to cause Central Diabetes Insipidus except ______
questions.solution:
Multiple Sclerosis is not a cause of Central Diabetes Insipidus.

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text: The most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation is?
questions.solution:
Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation is Papillary Carcinoma of thyroid.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

 

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A young man came with complaints of fever and severe headache. His CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is best suited for grading the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The CT scan reveals blood in the basal cistern (hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space) which is characteristic of Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH). Hess and Hunt scale is the most widely used scale to grade the severity of SAH.

Grade Description
1 Asymptomatic or minimal headache and slight nuchal rigidity
2 Moderate to severe headache, nuchal rigidity, cranial nerve palsy only
3 Drowsy, confusion, or mild focal deficit
4 Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity
5 Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity, moribund appearance

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage/ SAH:

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

Clinically presents as a thunderclap headache (often described by patients as the worst headache of life), neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness, and no focal neurological deficits. SAH can mostly present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

A painful third nerve palsy is typically the result of compression from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intraocular hemorrhages, classically subhyaloid, may be visible on fundoscopy. The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson’s Syndrome. 

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head shows hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space/ basal cistern, and lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia. Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the CSF withdrawn. CT angiography has a high sensitivity for aneurysms and AVMs, but digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.

The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.  Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

In patients with symptomatic vasospasm, triple H therapy is added as part of the therapeutic regimen.  

  • Induced hypertension- with vasopressors to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
  • Hypervolemia- to maintain the circulatory blood volume 
  • Hemodilution- accompanying change due to fluid therapy.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causes  Small, bland vegetations, usually attached to the line of closure of the valve leaflets?
questions.solution: Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) usually causes small, bland vegetations, usually attached at the line of closure of valve leaflets.

questions.text: Lemierre’s disease is a life-threatening condition of the head and neck that is most commonly associated with which of the following anaerobes?
questions.solution:
• Fusobacterium necrophorum
    • It is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus which is very pleomorphic.
    • It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections, one which is the complicated and life-threatening Lemierre’s disease.
  • Lemierre’s disease
    • It is also called postanginal septicemia and commonly occurs after infectious mononucleosis.
    • It is mostly seen in children and young adults.
    • This complicated infection of the head and neck usually starts with a sore throat which progresses to become very severe.
    • Septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein develops after the infection by F. necrophorum spreads into the lateral pharyngeal space.
    • This causes dysphagia, severe pain, neck swelling and stiffness.
    • The disease can progress to sepsis and metastatic infection of the lung and other sites. Mediastinitis or erosion of the carotid artery can also occur as the disease progresses.
    • Treatment includes IV antibiotics usually clindamycin or ampicillin/sulbactam and surgical drainage of purulent collections.

Clinical case: A 17 year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a higher fever and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. In this case, the organism that is most likely to be causing this complication is Fusobacterium necrophorum.

questions.text: An irritated wife brings her husband to the clinic. She says he grinds his teeth while sleeping and feels it is impossible to lie next to him. The patient feels jaw pain and headache the day following these episodes. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Botox can help prevent jaw joint complications
It is not precipitated by oromandibular dystonia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bruxism (teeth grinding). It can be precipitated by anxiety, stress, and oromandibular dystonia.

Sleep-related bruxism is commonly seen in the 1st or 2nd decade of life and can persist lifelong.

It can be prominently noted in mainly N1 and N2 NREM sleep and sometimes in REM sleep.

It may be associated with conditions such as:

  • Huntington’s disease
  • Cerebral palsy
  • Mental retardation.

Bruxism can be precipitated by anxiety and stress. It can lead to temporomandibular joint (TMJ) syndrome. Local injections of botulinum toxins (botox) into the masseter muscles can help in the prevention of dental and TMJ problems.

Bruxism can be seen secondary to the usage of entactogen drugs (Methylenedioxymethamphetamine – MDMA), amphetamine, cocaine, alcohol, and some serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

questions.text: Huntington’s disease (HD) is a neurodegenerative condition resulting from changes to which chromosome?
questions.solution:
• Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder.
  • It is caused by a CAG repeat expansion mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4, on the tip of its short arm.

questions.text: Which of the following neuropsychological tests is used to measure fine finger dexterity?
questions.solution:
• The grooved pegboard test is used to measure fine finger dexterity and motor speed as well as hand-eye coordination. In this test, the patient must put notched pegs into appropriate slotted holes in a board.
  • The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) measures the problem solving ability of a person. It requires a person to sort a long series of differently designed cards which is to be done by incorporating feedback from an examiner.
  • Shipley Scale-II is a brief pen and paper measure of multiple choice vocabulary, open-ended verbal abstraction and visual abstraction.
  • Rey-Osterreith Complex Figure Test is a visual-spatial assessment technique. It requires an individual to copy a highly complex geometrical configuration and then draw it from memory. It can be used on individuals, 9 years and above. Below is an example of a stimulus image used in this test.

questions.text: Which of the following concepts in the hypothesis testing is incorrect?

choices.text: Alpha is the maximum tolerable probability of a type 1 error being made
Beta is the probability of a type II error
When the null hypothesis is true but rejected, it is a type II error
P value can be more or less than alpha

questions.solution:
When the null hypothesis is true but is yet rejected, it is a type I error.

Type II errors are when an alternative hypothesis is rejected even though it is true.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Location of Type III gastric ulcer is:
questions.solution:
Type III gastric ulcer is located within 3 cm of Pylorus , and it mostly accompanies duodenal ulcer.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows:

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

questions.text: Which of the following is a natural insecticide?
questions.solution:
• Pyrethrum is a natural insecticide.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: Folie à deux is:

choices.text: A mental illness that is shared by two persons
An episode of two consecutive repetitive actions in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
Specific learning disability (SLD) having both reading and arithmetic components
Reactive attachment disorder (RAD) in two siblings born one after the other

questions.solution:
• Folie à deux is the term used for a mental illness shared by two persons.
  • If it is shared by three persons it is referred to as folie à trios and so on.
  • It is also called shared psychotic disorder and it is rare.
  • Folie à deux usually involves a common delusional system.
  • For example, if a man who has the delusion that he was abducted by aliens and then marries a woman who believes the same, they have a shared mental illness.
  • In the DSM-5, this is called ‘delusional symptoms in partner of the individual with delusional disorder’.

questions.text: The given ECG is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The ECG is characteristic of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.

Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy

  • The Epsilon wave (a small positive deflection buried in the end of the QRS complex) is the characteristic finding in ARVC.
  • T wave inversions in V1-3 is seen 85% of patients of ARVC.

questions.text: According to the WHO’s Mental Health Atlas, how many mental health workers did India have per 100,000 population, in 2014?
questions.solution:
• The WHO has designed the Mental Health Atlas Project which is used to collect and disseminate data related to mental health like policies, plans, financing, etc. in various countries.
  • This database is updated in regular intervals and was last updated in 2014.
  • According to the 2014 report on India, there were only 0.6 mental health workers per 100,000 population.
  • In specific, there were 0.30 psychiatrists and 0.07 psychologists per 100,000 population in India in 2014.
  • There were a total of 43 hospitals enlisted with inpatient care for mental health disorders, according to the same report.

questions.text: Which of the following is one of the metabolic fates of ornithine?

questions.text: The operation performed to repair an enterocele is:
questions.solution:
Moschowitz repair is done per abdominally to repair enterocoele.

ENTEROCELE

  • Enterocele is a herniation of the pouch of Douglas into the rectovaginal septum.
  • Moschowitz repair: In this procedure the pouch of Douglas is obliterated by several purse string sutures starting from below.
  • Whenever enterocoele is encountered during operation for prolapse it should be repaired. It can be repaired vaginally also during vaginal hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a structure involved in the circuit of Papez?
questions.solution:
• The Papez circuit is formed by projections from the hippocampus via the fornix to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, then via the anterior limb of the internal capsule to the cingulate gyrus, then back to the hippocampus via presubiculum, entorhinal cortex and the perforant pathway.
  • This circuit is part of the limbic system.
  • This circuit is important for short-term memory registration and retrieval; and in emotion.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chondromas?

choices.text: Most common site is in the small bones of the feet
If they arise on the surface of the bone, they are called enchondromas
Radiographically stable and asymptomatic chondromas also need curettage
Intralesional calcification is irregular – stippled or punctuate type

questions.solution:
• Chondromas are benign tumors of hyaline cartilage.
  • Small bones of the hand are the most common sites of these tumors but they can occur in any bone.
  • They usually arise in the medullary canal and these are referred to as enchondromas. If they arise on the surface of the bone (rare), they are termed as periosteal chondromas or juxtacortical chondromas.
  • In a radiograph, these enchondromas appear as benign lesion with intralesional calcification of irregular pattern which has a stippled or punctuate pattern.
  • Usually, no intervention is required if the enchondroma is radiographically stable and asymptomatic.
  • But symptomatic cases usually required extended curettage as a cure.
  • Recurrent rates are usually low in chondromas.

questions.text: Early stages of Alzheimer's disease in a patient have amyloid plaque depositions usually starting from which part of the brain?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer’s-associated amyloid plaques/deposits occur in the brain starting in the cortex, then sequentially in the hippocampus, basal ganglia, thalamus, and the basal forebrain. In the final stages, these plaques reach the brainstem and cerebellum.

Another major histopathological finding in Alzheimer’s Disease is the neurofibrillary tangles which are a type of intracellular inclusion body.

Note: Atrophy in Alzheimer’s disease begins in the entorhinal cortex.

questions.text: A high-functioning 88 year old woman was brought home from the hospital after treatment for a small stroke. She wakes up the next morning in her bedroom complaining that her usual housemaid was not the same person as before but is an impersonator and also that her bedroom was not genuine, but an exact replica of her actual bedroom. She most likely has:
questions.solution:
• This case describes a case of reduplicative paramnesia.
  • Reduplicative paramnesia is a type of delusional misidentification syndrome; of which other types include Capgras syndrome and Fregoli syndrome.
  • Reduplicative paramnesia involves an individual having the delusion that persons and/or places have been replaced by identical ones.
  • There is a significant overlap with Capgras syndrome, although in Capgras, the individual has only the delusions that a person (often someone they know) has been replaced by an identical look-like.
  • If a delusion of place being replaced comes into the picture or if a person believes he/she has been in two places at the same time, it is usually reduplicative paramnesia. This usually occurs following a brain injury due to trauma or stroke.
  • Fregoli syndrome includes the delusion that strangers are familiar people appearing in disguises.
  • Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome is a prion disease that manifests with cerebellar ataxia and motor deficits. It has familial autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and presents in the 4th or 5th decade of life, usually.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy visits his doctor to discuss his opioid addiction. 2 years ago he tried to cut down on his opioid consumption but developed excessive sweating, lacrimation, and yawning. He wants to quit now with the help of medications. Which of the following will not be useful in this patient?
questions.solution:
Disulfiram will not be useful for the treatment of opioid detoxification. It is used in cases of chronic alcoholism.

Two years back when the patient tried to cut down his opioid intake, he experienced opioid withdrawal symptoms. Symptoms begin 8-10 hours after the last consumed dose. Initially, symptoms include

  • Lacrimation
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Yawning
  • Sweating 

Later, the patient develops

  • Restless sleep
  • Weakness, chills, gooseflesh (“cold turkey”)
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Muscle aches and involuntary movements (“kicking the habit”)
  • Hyperpnea
  • Hyperthermia
  • Hypertension

The treatment for the opioid withdrawal includes:

Opioid agonists (methadone) or partial agonists (buprenorphine) administered orally or sublingually may be substituted for injectable narcotics. 

Lofexidine and clonidine are alpha 2 agonists which can ameliorate symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Lofexidine is the first non-opioid treatment for managing opioid withdrawal symptoms in adults approved by the FDA in 2018.

Naltrexone, a long-acting opioid antagonist, is used as an adjunct if the patient is already opioid-free. Administration of naltrexone to patients that are opioid-dependent will precipitate acute withdrawal symptoms.

Related Pearl: Classification of Opioids

Naturally Occurring:

  • Morphine
  • Codeine (methyl morphine)
  • Papaverine
  • Thebaine

Semisynthetic:

  • Heroin (diacetyl morphine)
  • Dihydromorphone, morphinone
  • Thebaine derivatives (e.g., etorphine, buprenorphine)

Synthetic:

  • Morphinan series (e.g., levorphanol, butorphanol)
  • Diphenylpropylamine series (e.g., methadone)
  • Benzomorphan series (e.g., pentazocine)
  • Phenylpiperidine series (e.g., meperidine, fentanyl, sufentanil, alfentanil, remifentanil)

questions.text: Eye coordination and binocular vision develops by
questions.solution:
• Binocular vision and eye co-ordination develop by 3 months.
  • Depth perception develops around 5 to 6 months of age.
  • Total development of fixation of light occurs at 6 to 8 weeks.

questions.text: Denial of one’s own deficits or handicaps is termed as:
questions.solution:
• Anosognosia
    • It is the ‘lack of insight’ which usually manifests as an inability to perceive their own symptoms or denial of them or lack of concern for their current difficulties.
    • It is commonly associated with certain types of frontotemporal lobar dementia (FTD) and with traumatic brain injury (particularly to the right hemisphere).
  • Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize familiar faces that is not due to impaired visual acuity or level of consciousness.
  • Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.
  • Nihilism is a delusion of the nonexistence of the self or part of the self. It is also a philosophical doctrine of total rejection of established values or extreme skepticism regarding moral and value judgments.
  • Nihilistic delusion is a delusional disorder where one believes that the world and everything related to it have ceased to exist.

questions.text: False about gastrointestinal stromal tumor is

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of Cajal
Most common symptom is abdominal mass

questions.solution:
Most common symptom of GIST– bleeding.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor:

  • Most common mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC).
  • Stomach is the most common site.
  • Almost all GISTs express
    • c-KIT (CD117)
    • PDGF receptor A
    • CD34
  • Most common symptom – bleeding
  • Investigation of choice for primary – CT scan.
  • Investigation of choice for recurrent GIST – PET-CT.
  • Route of metastasis – hematogenous.
  • Treatment: Resection with negative margin.
  • Chemotherapy with imatinib, sunitinib.
  • Prognosis – mainly depends on tumor size.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

  • Age ≥65 years
