questions.solution: • Freud ascribed four principal characteristics to instinctual drives namely source, impetus, aim and object.

questions.text: The most common extradural spinal tumor is _________.
questions.solution:
The most common extradural spinal tumor is a metastatic tumor.

Most common location of spinal tumors: Extradural

  • Extradural tumors account for approximately 55% of spinal tumors.
  • Spinal metastases most commonly occur in the thoracic and lumbar vertebral bodies because the greatest volume of red bone marrow is found in these regions.
  • The most common primary sources of spine metastasis are lymphoma, lung, breast, and prostate.
  • Most spinal metastases create osteolytic lesions
  • Ependymomas are the most common intramedullary tumors in adults.
  • Astrocytomas are the most common intramedullary tumors in children.

questions.text: All are true about Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy except?

choices.text: Optic atrophy in one eye is followed by the other eye

questions.solution:
In  Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy the pupillary reaction is normal.

Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy

  • The genetic disease characterized by the mutation at maternal mitochondrial DNA.
  • The most common cause of inherited blindness due to the mitochondrial chromosomal anomaly.

Clinical features

  • Young male
  • Bilateral acute painless loss of vision
  • Optic neuritis in one eye is followed by the other eye
  • Optic atrophy in one eye is followed by the other eye
  • The pupillary reaction is normal
  • Centrocaecal scotoma
  • Cannot be controlled by drug since genetically controlled

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the dynamics of histamine in the brain?

choices.text: Histamine is a substrate for monoamine oxidase which oxidizes it to imidazole acetic acid
Histamine concentration in the brain is controlled by its general concentration in plasma and by its synthesis in the brain
Histaminergic neurotransmission is involved in the mechanism of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disorders
H3 receptors have a higher degree of constitutive activity, in vivo

questions.solution:
• Constitutive activity
    • Histamine H3 receptors have a higher degree of constitutive activity, in vivo which is a striking characteristic of these receptors. 
    • All histamine receptors have been proven to have different degrees of constitutive activity.
    • Constitutive activity is the ability of G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) to signal without the presence of an agonist.
    • In other words, it is the spontaneous isomerization of a receptor into an active state even in the absence of a ligand.
  • Histamine metabolism
    • The metabolism of histamine has two pathways.
    • Oxidation of histamine by diamine oxidase (DAO) which leads to the formation of imidazole acetic acid.
    • Methylation of histamine by histamine N-methyltransferase (HMT) produces tele-methylhistamine (t-MH). This is then metabolized by monoamine oxidase-B (MAO-B) to produce tele-methylimidazole acetic acid (t-MIAA).
    • Remember: Histamine is a substrate for DAO and not MAO.
  • Histamine in the brain
    • Histamine does not cross the blood-brain barrier and its concentration in the brain is not affected by its general concentration in plasma.
    • Thus, histamine concentration in the brain is controlled by its synthesis in the brain.
    • The brain itself stores and releases histamine from more than one type of cell like mast cells.
  • Conditions like multiple sclerosis, Alzheimer’s disease, Down syndrome, Tourette’s syndrome, etc. have been associated to alterations in the brain histamine system.
  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) diseases are a group of heterogeneous neuromuscular disorders which have similar clinical presentations whose pathophysiology varies from peripheral demyelination to neuronal abnormalities.

questions.text: Calnexin is mainly involved in:

choices.text: Signaling release of calcium from endoplasmic reticulum

questions.solution:
Calnexin is a lectin chaperone that is involved in the folding of glycoproteins and it is located in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum.

It binds to various proteins like the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens and plasma proteins. It makes the proteins stay within the endoplasmic reticulum until they are properly folded.

Calreticulin is another chaperone and calcium-binding protein, similar to calnexin but it is not membrane-bound.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of migraine comes to you complaining of nausea, blurred vision, neck stiffness, and pain around 4 hours ago. You hear her describing her sudden headache as the worst she has ever had. What would be the next best course of action?

choices.text: Intramuscular injection of ketorolac and consider prochlorperazine for nausea
Arrange for an urgent lumbar puncture

questions.solution:
The complaint of a worst-ever, sudden-onset headache is generally linked to a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Thus, the next step in this patient is to obtain an urgent non-contrast CT to confirm this diagnosis.

Her symptoms like nausea, stiffness in the neck, and blurred vision can also be present in SAH. 

Thuderclap headache is a variant of migraine that can mimic the presentation of SAH. However, before diagnosing a patient to have thunderclap migraine, a proper workup to exclude an intracranial pathology is required.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua
   Cluster headache Paroxysmal hemicrania   SUNCT/SUNA
Gender  Males>females Female=Males Female=Males
Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day

Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes

Cutaneous trigger No No Yes

Prophylaxis

  • Lithium

  • Steroids 
  • Verapamil

  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

questions.text: A person is on herbal medications. If he has to undergo any surgery, the most appropriate advice given would be:

choices.text: Stop them 2 days before surgery since they might cause adverse effects
Continue them along with anti-allergic medications
Stop them as early as 2 weeks since they might cause increased operative bleeding

questions.solution:
• Herbal medications should be discontinued at least 2 weeks before surgery due to adverse perioperative events associated with their use.
  • For example, the use of garlic and ginger has been associated with increased operative bleeding when whereas others may increase allergic reactions.
  • They may interfere with the action of the anesthetic drugs used.
  • Besides, the composition of herbal medicines may be unpredictable leading to numerous adverse effects and drug interactions.

questions.text: An 85 year old man who is legally blind due to severe macular degeneration reports seeing images of colorful animals and people. He realizes he is blind and understands that these are hallucinations. This man most probably has:
questions.solution:
• Charles Bonnet syndrome is most commonly seen in the elderly.

questions.text: Inhibitory post synaptic potential is due to
questions.solution:
Inhibitory post synaptic potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of Cl- ions.

IPSP

Inhibitory post synaptic potential (IPSP) is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.

  • The inhibitory neurotransmitters involved are Glycine and GABA.
  • The binding of these neurotransmitters cause influx of chloride ions leading to hyperpolarization. (Influx of chloride ions / Efflux of Potassium ions cause hyperpolarization)
  • The hyperpolarization makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: Free and combined chlorines in water are separately identified by:
questions.solution:
• Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both combined and free chlorines in water separately.
  • Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorines together.
  • Chloronomes are devices used to regulate dose of chlorine gas used for disinfection.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: In a right-handed person, dressing apraxia can be localized to:
questions.solution:
• Dressing apraxia localizes to the right hemisphere (non-dominant), specifically right parietal lobe lesions.
  • In dressing apraxia, patients find it difficult to complete the relatively complex task of dressing.
  • Impaired tactile and visuospatial coordination plus a degree of hemineglect can explain why this occurs in right parietal lobe lesions.
  • Hemineglect becomes obvious when patients leave the left side dishevelled or unclothed.

questions.text: Esthiomene is a clinical finding that is associated with ___________
questions.solution:
Esthiomene refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia, which is seen in the tertiary stage of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

Lymphogranuloma venerum affects sexually active adults. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes causing lymphangitis. There is infiltration of polymorphonuclear lymphocytes and plasma cells. The necrotic areas coalesce and enlarge to form a stellate abscess. Patients present with genital ulceration, rectal bleeding, and lymphadenopathy.

There are three stages of the disease: 

Primary - The incubation period is 3-30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals. 

Secondary - It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterized by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy - groove sign. The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts. 

Tertiary - Genito-anorectal syndrome is seen. This occurs years after untreated primary infection.  There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation which causes ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men.

The given image shows esthiomene, a feature of lymphogranuloma venereum. 

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Most common malignant brain tumour of childhood is?
questions.solution:
The most common malignant brain tumour of childhood age group is Medulloblastoma.

Medulloblastoma :

  • Primitive neuroectodermal tumor is the most common type of medulloblastoma.
  • Most occur in the first decade of life, but there is a second peak around age 30.
  • It is the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor.
  • They are usually midline.
  • Most occur in the cerebellum and present with symptoms of increased ICP.
  • Histologic characteristics : densely packed small round cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm, generally not encapsulated.
  • Frequently disseminate within the CNS
  • Should undergo surgical resection followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following lamina is referred to as the Striae of the Gennari ?
questions.solution: In the striate cortex, the external band of Baillarger - lamina IV is well defined as “the Stria / White line of Gennari”.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of drug abuse and multiple unstable relationships. You notice scars on the patient’s forearm that look self-inflicted. The patient also mentions a long-lasting feeling of emptiness and anger issues in relationships. Which of the following personality disorders is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is indicative of borderline personality disorder.

Borderline personality disorder belongs to cluster B of personality disorders. Diagnostic features of this disorder include at least five of the following:

  • Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment.
  • Unstable or intense interpersonal relationships, alternating between idealization and devaluation.
  • Markedly and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self.
  • Impulsivity in at least two potentially self-damaging areas (spending, sex, reckless driving, substance abuse, binge eating)
  • Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behaviors.
  • Instability of affect due to marked reactivity of mood
  • Chronic feelings of emptiness
  • Inappropriately intense anger or difficulty controlling anger
  • Stress-related, transient paranoid ideation or dissociative symptoms.

Associated features can include tendency to undermine self when close to reaching a goal and intense attachment to non-human objects like pets and material things than to other humans.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered to be involved in the etiology of conduct disorder?

choices.text: Impaired functioning of the parietal lobes

questions.solution:
Factors involved in the etiology of conduct disorder

  • Biological factors
    • Heritable factors and genetic factors.
    • Physiological factors: Low levels of arousal
    • Neuroendocrinologic factors: Low basal cortisol levels
    • Neurotransmitter factors: Low catecholaminergic activity in CNS and disturbed serotonin neurotransmission
    • Neuroanatomic factors: Functional deficits in prefrontal cortex, frontal lobe dysfunction
    • Neurotoxic factors: Maternal prenatal smoking and alcohol use
  • Psychological factors
    • Cognitive factors: Executive cognitive function deficits
    • Parent child factors: Poor parenting, low parental warmth
    • Traumatic factors: Physical abuse, sexual abuse, neglect
    • Parental factors: Witnessing domestic violence, criminality of parents, alcoholism in parents, etc.
  • Sociological factors
    • Peer factors: Rejection by peers, bullying
    • Social factors: Poverty, overcrowding, poor housing, etc.

questions.text: Following road traffic accident, a man developed head injury resulting in a defect in the association fibres. Which of the following is not classified under these fibres?
questions.solution:
Corona radiata is not classified under association fibers. It an example of projection fiber.

Option A: Cingulum is a long association fiber connecting the frontal and parietal lobes with the parahippocampal and temporal cortical region.

Option C: Fornix is an example of association fiber but only Hippocampal commissure of fornix is a commisural fibre as it has transverse fibers connecting the two crura of the fornix.

Option D: Arcuate fasciculus is a short association fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata
